awd_titl_txt: Advancing Technologies for Measuring the Largest Angular Scale CMB
awd_abstract_narration:
Cosmology is the big-picture study of the universe. One of the most important means for research in this field is to make careful measurements of the very faint radiation known as the “cosmic microwave background.” This radiation is very faint. Also, there are other radiation signals from non-cosmological sources that must be distinguished. The technology and instrumentation to allow such experiments to make the needed measurements is a major challenge. Over the years progress has been made studying ever fainter aspects of this background radiation that are then used to test competing theoretical models. To enable such scientific progress, the underlying technologies must be improved further as will be undertaken in this project. The team will provide instrumentation training for the next generation of scientists and will leverage this project to enhance their public education efforts.

This  project seeks to  develop  technology for an  enhanced  polarimeter  to study  reionization  and  inflation cosmology on the Cosmology Large Angular Scale Surveyor (CLASS).  CLASS is built to measure the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) polarization on angular scales greater than 10 degrees (corresponding to spherical harmonic multipole moments  near 20).  The survey looks to produce a high fidelity polarization map over 70% of the sky at frequencies near the Galactic foreground minimum.  This project will develop enhanced larger format detector arrays and silicon optics that will improve CLASS sensitivity to ultimately allow better understanding of the early universe and fundamental physics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project created key technologies to measure the polarization of the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) on the largest scales. The CMB is light from the Big Bang, and measuring its largest-scale polarization will tell us how long ago the first stars lit up the universe and will provide insights into the very first moments of the universe. The technologies developed are commissioned on the Cosmology Large Angular Scale Surveyor (CLASS), which operates several CMB telescopes in the Andes of Northern Chile.

The first technology developed was high-sensitivity detectors. These detectors are cooled to 0.1 Kelvin (-273 degrees Celsius) to decrease the ambient thermal noise that would otherwise overwhelm the faint CMB signal. They have precisely defined frequencies at which they operate, which for these detectors are centered on 90 GHz (3 mm wavelength). This frequency is optimal for CMB in that it avoids interference from the atmosphere and our own galaxy. The detectors significantly improved the sensitivity of the CLASS telescopes, and, in turn, CLASS is testing the efficacy of different detector design choices. 

The second technology developed was a reflective half-wave plate polarization modulator (RHWP). Polarization modulation is a key technology for separating the CMB signal from the noise in the same way that Amplitude Modulation (AM) Radio separates the signal of the broadcaster from radio noise (static). The RHWP created in this project is significantly larger than previous half-wave plate modulators, increasing the optical throughput of the telescope. In replacing the original CLASS polarization modulator, the RHWP has doubled the speed at which CLASS measures the CMB polarization, and, in turn, CLASS is testing the efficacy of different modulator technologies.

The primary broader impact of this project was the training of young scientists and engineers. In total, five graduate students and three undergraduates conducted significant research on the project. One postdoc and three early-career research scientists developed leadership skills by designing their own technology development plans and leading student research teams. Additionally, project team members contributed to cosmology modules that have been used in Maryland high schools, and which are distributed online. The results of the project were published through international conferences, journal articles, and, in popular form, through social media.
